These data show that two 3C-like proteinase-mediated cleavages, at dipeptide bonds Gln-4068/Ser-4069 and Gln-4995/Ala-4996, release the putative RNA polymerase domain from the HCV 229E 1ab polyprotein in the form of a 926-aminoacid polypeptide with a calculated molecular mass of 105.5 kDa.

In this study, we have identified, in virus-infected cells, a 105-kDa viral polypeptide that is encoded in the HCV 229E ORFs 1a and 1b. The identity of the polypeptide has been established by reactivity with monoclonal antibodies of defined specificity. We have also shown that the 105-kDa polypeptide is released from the gene 1encoded polyprotein precursor, pp1ab, by cleavage at the dipeptide bonds Gln-4068/Ser-4069 and Gln-4995/ Ala-4996, a reaction that is mediated by the HCV 229E 3C-like proteinase.

The detection of coronavirus gene 1-encoded polypeptides in the virus-infected cell is proving to be a laborious task. The results shown here, and our previous work on the expression of the HCV 229E 3C-like proteinase (Ziebuhr et al., 1995) , indicate that, at least in the early stages of infection, these proteins are present in the cell in exceedingly low amounts. Indeed, the data suggest that it is only possible to detect polymerase translation products after the infection has progressed into the phase of genomic and subgenomic mRNA amplification. Also, as may have been predicted from in vitro studies on the level of HCV 229E mRNA 1 ribosomal frameshifting , we have found it more difficult to identify pp1ab-derived products compared to those derived from pp1a. For example, our attempts to immunoprecipitate the 105-kDa polypeptide using polyclonal antiserum, an approach which has proven successful for the detection of the HCV 229E 3C-like proteinase, have failed to produce convincing results. Obviously, if it is only possible to detect stable translation products as they accumulate in the virus-infected cell, it is going to be difficult to obtain detailed information on the expression and processing of the HCV 229E 1a and 1ab polyproteins. On the basis of the data obtained so far, a quantitative comparison of the amounts of ORF 1a-encoded (Ziebuhr et al., 1995) and ORF 1b-encoded polypeptides is, in our opinion, not possible. For example, the characteristics of the primary and secondary antibodies and the immunological assays that have been used in these studies are very different. Also, the genesis of gene 1-encoded polypeptides involves proteolytic processing, and we do not have any data on the kinetics of this process.
